questions.text: A mother has a pearly white papule on her forehead (as shown in the image below) which her infant also develops. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
The image shows pearly white umbilicated wart-like lesions with a characteristic dimple at the center, suggestive of molluscum contagiosum, which is caused by pox virus.

The age of peak incidence is between 2 and 5 years. In children, it is mainly caused by the type I molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV-1). There is a relatively higher incidence of MCV‐2 type in adults and HIV infection. Sexually transmitted molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area.

It has an incubation period of 2 weeks to 6 months. Widespread and refractory lesions are seen most commonly in HIV or patients on immunosuppressive therapy.

It is characterized by the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion bodies called Henderson-Patterson bodies or molluscum bodies. Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon is seen, that is, new lesions develop along lines of trauma.

Treatment is usually not required, and lesions are likely to resolve spontaneously. Stimulation of the immune response can be done after destructive or inflammatory therapies with salicylic acid, trichloroacetic acid, and imiquimod. Cryotherapy when done needs to be repeated at 3-4 week intervals. Extensive lesions are treated with an antiviral agent like cidofovir.

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are both severe mucocutaneous reactions, characterized by blistering and epithelial sloughing. The two terms describe phenotypes within a severity spectrum, where SJS is the less extensive form and TEN is the more extensive

questions.text: A girl presented with itching and oozing from an earlobe lesion after wearing nickel earrings. What test will you do to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of allergic contact dermatitis and the diagnosis is made by a patch test.

Allergic contact dermatitis is a reaction to a substance (allergen) that causes an eruption only in those individuals previously sensitized by the same molecule. It is a delayed-type of hypersensitivity (Type IV) reaction. It presents as pruritis and an eczematous eruption in sites where contact has taken place with the etiological agent/allergen.

Nickel is the most frequent contact allergen. Most of its salts, for example, nickel chloride and nickel sulfate, are readily soluble in water and sweat and have strong sensitizing properties. Jewelry and metal components of clothing are the usual sources of nickel in prolonged contact with the skin. 

Patch tests are used to identify the etiologic agent(s) of allergic contact dermatitis. Patches are usually applied to the back and removed 48 hours after application. The skin where the patch was applied is examined with readings taken 1 hour after removal and again 48 hours later.

Treatment of includes

  • Avoidance of the allergen (for example, further use of nickel‐plated objects should be avoided in this case)
  • A topical clioquinol–steroid combination can be considered as a treatment (clioquinol is known to chelate nickel)

questions.text: "System of lines on the human skin which the linear naevi and dermatoses follow" are called ________
questions.solution:
Blaschko’s lines are described as a ‘system of lines on the human skin which the linear naevi and dermatoses follow’.

Many naevoid skin lesions display an arrangement following these lines. The lines do not correspond to any known nervous, vascular or lymphatic structures, but represent developmental growth pattern within the skin

Other options:

  • Langer's lines/Langer lines of skin tension/cleavage lines: 
    • They are topological lines drawn on a map of the human body.
    • They correspond to the natural orientation of collagen fibers in the dermis and are generally parallel to the orientation of the underlying muscle fibers.
    • They have importance in cosmetic surgery.
  • Kraissl's lines are a set of anatomical skin lines. They differ from Langer's lines in that unlike Langer's lines, which are defined in term of collagen orientation, Kraissl's lines are the lines of maximum skin tension. Langer's lines were defined in cadavers, Kraissl's lines have been defined in living individuals.
  • Dermatomes: Sensory innervation follows well‐defined dermatomes, with some overlap between adjacent dermatomes.

questions.solution:
Human papillomavirus 6 & 11 (6 >11) are the most common cause of anogenital warts (also known as Condyloma Accuminata).

questions.text: Given below is the Direct immunofluorescence image of a patient with transient blisters over skin in seborrheic regions without involving the mucosa. What is the pattern seen in this case?

choices.text: Fish net pattern in Pemphigus Vulgaris
Dilapidated bricks in Hailey Hailey disease

questions.solution:
The intercellular space staining in Direct Immunofluorescence causes fishnet appearance in both pemphigus vulgaris and foliaceous. However, transient blisters in seborrheic regions (scalp, face, chest and upper back) without the involvement of mucosa points towards Pemphigus foliaceous.

  • Pemphigus foliaceous (PF) is a more superficial acantholytic blistering (Subcorneal blisters) disease when compared to Pemphigus vulgaris. (Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by intraepidermal acantholytic blisters).
  • The mucosa is spared in PF while it is involved in PV.
  • PF patients exhibit shallow erosions associated with erythema, scale, and crust formation while PV patients have intact blisters. In fact, mild cases of PF resemble severe seborrheic dermatitis.
  • Severe PF may cause extensive exfoliation. Sun exposure (ultraviolet irradiation) may be an aggravating factor.
  • PF has immunopathologic features in common with PV.
  • Direct immunofluorescence microscopy of perilesional skin demonstrates IgG on the surface of keratinocytes.
  • Similarly, patients with PF have circulating IgG autoantibodies directed against the surface of keratinocytes. In PF, autoantibodies are directed against Dsg-1 only. (In PV, autoantibodies are directed against Dsg-3 & Dsg-1).

questions.text: Which of the following tests would you use to differentiate between nevus anemicus and vitiligo in a patient?
questions.solution:
Diascopy is a test that helps to differentiate between nevus anemicus and vitiligo.

Nevus anemicus is secondary to a localized area of vasoconstriction, and diascopy of the adjacent skin reveals a color identical to that of the ‘depigmented’ area, since other pigments are unaltered. In vitiligo, the lesion appears paler, since there is a loss of melanin.

Diascopy is a clinical maneuver performed to assess superficial erythema in dermatological conditions. In this procedure, a glass slide or a stiff, clear, colorless piece of plastic is pressed onto the skin to compress blood out of small vessels, in order to allow evaluation of other colors. Vessels can be seen to blanch and fill, by varying the amount of pressure on the skin, which is different for different conditions.

The purpose of this procedure is to empty blood from the superficial vessels to determine if skin redness is due to blood present within the vessels or extravasated onto the skin.

Diascopy is of particular value in the following conditions:

  • Granulomatous conditions: A translucent brownish color is seen on diascopy, known as ‘apple jelly’ nodules. They are seen in all 3 of sarcoidosis, granuloma annulare, and lupus vulgaris.
  • Differentiation between nevus anemicus and nevus depigmentosus: On diascopy, nevus anemicus (congenital white patch of vasoconstriction) becomes indistinguishable with the merging of the lesion into the surrounding skin. However, the border of nevus depigmentosus remains unaltered after diascopy.
  • Spider nevus: Application of medium pressure to a spider nevus can compress radiating arterioles and allow visualization of pulsatile flow in the feeding vessel.
  • Differentiation between erythema (vasodilation) and purpura (extravasated blood): Erythema blanches on compression of vessels, while purpura and petechiae do not blanch on compression.

Wood's lamp examination can also be used to distinguish between vitiligo and nevus anemicus.

In vitiligo, the depigmented areas appear milky white, due to a loss of melanin, while in nevus anemicus, the pallor completely disappears, since it is secondary to localized vasoconstriction.

questions.text: You notice the following skin finding in a child presenting to the dermatology OPD. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts phrynoderma which can be managed by Vitamin A supplementation.

Phrynoderma (toad skin) is common in children in the 5 - 15 year age group. Earlier thought to be purely due to Vitamin A deficiency, now has been associated with other nutritional deficiencies including B complex, ribofla­vin, vitamin C, vitamin E, essential fatty acids, and malnutrition

It is a non-specific finding that can be associated with: 

• Liver cirrhosis.
• Malabsorption syndromes.
• Anorexia nervosa.
• Alcohol abuse.
• Nutritional deficiency following bariatric surgery.

It manifests as groups of papules, each one around 3–4 mm in diameter, with a central keratotic plug. The papules have a follicular distribution and give the skin a rough texture. The elbows and knees are the most commonly affected areas but the buttocks and extensor surfaces of the limbs may also be affected.

All patients with phrynoderma should have their Vitamin A levels measured. Treatment involves the correction of poor diet and administration of multivitamin preparations containing Vitamin A.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy had painful sores in the mouth with a rash over the hands along with fever. Which of these is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The presence of fever, along with painful sores in the mouth and small, tense vescicles with surrounding erythema on the palms and soles in a child point towards the diagnosis of hand-foot-mouth disease. The most common cause of which worldwide is coxackievirus A16. 

Spread is by droplets or faecal contamination and the incubation period is 7 days. The fever is generally mild, and is followed by the appearance of lesions. The characteristic lesions are slightly oval, with a grey blister roof and a narrow rim of erythema. The oral lesions are aphthoid and are less painful than aphthous ulcers.

Only symptomatic treatment is given. The lesions generally disappear in 7 - 10 days.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman, with psoriasis, was found to have manic depression. She was started on a medication that resulted in severe exacerbation of the psoriatic rash as shown in the image below. Which of the following medications is likely to have caused it?
questions.solution:
The patient has developed a severe exacerbation of psoriasis, secondary to lithium administration for her manic depression.

Various factors contribute to the exacerbation of psoriasis. Drugs inducing/exacerbating psoriasis:

  1. Beta-blockers
  2. Synthetic antimalarials
  3. NSAIDS
  4. Lithium
  5. ACE inhibitors & angiotensin receptor blockers
  6. Interferon alpha
  7. Tetracycline
  8. Terbinafine
  9. Gemfibrozil

Other environmental and immunological factors that may trigger psoriasis are:

  • Infections- beta-hemolytic streptococci can trigger guttate psoriasis, viral infections like HIV
  • Alcohol misuse and smoking
  • Emotional stress
  • Trauma - Koebner phenomenon
  • Winter 
  • Sunlight

questions.text: Esthiomene is a clinical finding that is associated with ___________
questions.solution:
Esthiomene refers to hypertrophic enlargement with ulceration of the external genitalia, which is seen in the tertiary stage of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV).

Lymphogranuloma venerum affects sexually active adults. The organism spreads from the site of the initial lesion to the regional lymph nodes causing lymphangitis. There is infiltration of polymorphonuclear lymphocytes and plasma cells. The necrotic areas coalesce and enlarge to form a stellate abscess. Patients present with genital ulceration, rectal bleeding, and lymphadenopathy.

There are three stages of the disease: 

Primary - The incubation period is 3-30 days. The genital lesions may be painful or painless. The patient usually presents with symptoms of hemorrhagic proctitis. The condition is common among homosexuals. 

Secondary - It may take days to weeks for the disease to manifest. It is characterized by tender unilateral or bilateral inguinal or femoral lymphadenopathy - groove sign. The lymph nodes coalesce to form painful buboes which rupture and form fistulae and sinus tracts. 

Tertiary - Genito-anorectal syndrome is seen. This occurs years after untreated primary infection.  There is lymphatic obstruction due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis. This results in genital lymphoedema and inflammation which causes ulceration and chronic granulomatous fibrosis, resulting in esthiomene in women and elephantiasis in men.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is unlikely to present with skin lesions on the shin?
questions.solution:
Hypothyroidism is unlikely to present with skin lesions on shin. Myxedema (severe hypothyroidism) and pretibial myxedema are different entities. Pretibial myxedema is the infiltrative dermopathy (mucin deposition) seen over shin in Grave's disease, a type of hyperthyroidism. 

Other options :

Option B: Diabetes: Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is classically seen on the anterior leg.

Option A: Sarcoidosis: Erythema nodosum may be seen on the anterior leg.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of patients with plaque psoriasis is an interleukin-23 inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Guselkumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits interleukin-23 by binding to its p19 subunit. By this, it inhibits the pro-inflammatory actions of IL-23, decreasing cytokine and chemokine release.

It is indicated for use in moderate-to-severe plaque psoriasis, when the patient is a possible candidate for systemic therapy or if early systemic therapy is the logical option for a patient. It is given as a subcutaneous injection at a dose of 100mg at week 0, week 4 and every 8 weeks thereafter.

Adverse effects of guselkumab include the risk of general infections and upper respiratory tract infections (most common). Other adverse events include headache, injection site reaction, arthralgia, diarrhea, gastroenteritis, and tinea infections.

 Other Options:

  • Brodalumab is a fully human IL-17RA monoclonal antibody that inhibits the interaction of IL-17 with cytokines. It also received approval for usage in plaque psoriasis.
  • Ixekizumab is also indicated for use in plaque psoriasis. It neutralizes the pro-inflammatory effects of IL-17A by inhibition.
  • Etanercept is a tumor necrosis factor-α (TNFα) inhibitor. It is used in the treatment of conditions like ankylosing spondylitis, rheumatoid arthritis (adult and juvenile), psoriatic arthritis and plaque psoriasis.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with multibacillary leprosy. For how long should she be treated and monitored for relapse, respectively?
questions.solution:
A patient with multibacillary leprosy should be treated for 12 months and monitored for relapse for at least 5 years.

Leprosy is a chronic infectious disease that mainly affects the skin, the peripheral nerves, upper respiratory tract mucosa, and the eyes caused by Mycobacterium leprae. If left untreated, it can lead to permanent damage to the skin, nerves, limbs, and eyes.

Leprosy is classified as paucibacillary (PB) or multibacillary (MB). Paucibacillary leprosy refers to cases with 1-5 skin lesions, no or only 1 involved nerve, with no bacilli in a skin smear. Multibacillary leprosy refers to cases with >5 skin lesions, with >1 nerve involvement, or with the presence of bacilli in the skin smear, irrespective of the number of skin lesions.

WHO recommends multidrug therapy (MDT) for the treatment of leprosy. The currently recommended MDT regimen includes dapsone, rifampicin and clofazimine. It is given for 6 months in paucibacillary leprosy and 12 months for multibacillary cases. 

The majority of the cases are cured following MDT, however, relapse may occur. A multibacillary patient has to be monitored for 5 years and the paucibacillary patient has to be monitored for 2 years after completion of treatment.

questions.text: All of the following are clinical manifestations of dermatomyositis, except:
questions.solution:
Salmon rash is not a dermatological manifestation of Dermatomyositis.

A. Pathognomonic manifestations

  • Gottron's papules: Violaceous, erythematous papules overlying the dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal, elbow or knee joints, as shown in the image below
  • Gottron's sign: Symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques, often atrophic, in the same distribution as Gottron's papules

B. Characteristic manifestations

  • Shawl sign/V-sign: Fixed macular erythema, across the shoulders and outer arms(Shawl distribution)
  • Heliotrope rash: Purplish color rash, often itchy, associated with swelling around the eye.
  • Periungual telangiectasias: Dilated capillaries of the nail folds
  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the skin of the tips and sides of the fingers, resulting in irregular, dirty-appearing lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual laborer.

C. Compatible manifestations

  • Poikiloderma atrophicans vasculare
  • Calcinosis cutis

D. Less common Manifestations

  • Facial swelling
  • Malignancy
  • Erythroderma
  • Lichen planus

The salmon rash is seen in guttate psoriasis and still's disease.

  • Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodeling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash.
  • Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as “mechanic’s hands.”
  • Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient came with complaints of non-scarring alopecia in the vertex region of his head. Histological examination shows loss of hair with haemorrhage into the follicular areas and mild perinuclear lymphocytic infiltrate.  What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario depicting a young adult presenting with non-scarring alopecia in the vertex region and histology showing perifollicular hemorrhage is suggestive of trichotillomania (trichotillosis). 

Trichotillomania has to be differentiated from alopecia areata (Option A). Trichotillomania presents with incomplete hair loss within a patch with varying lengths of hair whereas alopecia areata shows smooth hairless patch with sparing of white hairs. Regular pitting of nails and exclamation mark hairs are seen in alopecia areata. When the diagnosis is uncertain, a scalp biopsy can be done. Perifollicular hemorrhage is characteristic of trichotillomania while peribulbar lymphocytic infiltrate is diagnostic of alopecia areata. 

Trichotillomania is classified under obsessive-compulsive and related disorders. It is characterized by recurrent body-focused repetitive behavior (hair pulling) and repeated attempts to decrease or stop the behavior. It is commonly seen in females. The hair loss is commonly seen over the vertex but can involve eyelashes, eyebrows, and beard.

The most effective treatment for trichotillosis is habit-reversal training (HRT).

Other options:

Option B: Telogen effluvium is diffuse hair loss resulting in non-scarring alopecia due to loss of telogen hairs due to fever, pregnancy, hypothyroidism or anemia.

Option C: Tinea infection shows patchy hair loss, resulting in non-scarring/scarring alopecia. Easy pluckability, broken hairs and wood's lamp positivity are features.

questions.text: Syringoma is a benign tumor of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Syringoma is a benign tumor of the sweat ducts. 

It mostly appears during adolescence, usually in females. It consists of small dermal papules, that may be yellow in color or transluscent and cystic. They have a variable size ranging from 1-5mm. They may resemble milia. 

Syringomas usually are distributed bilaterally and symmetrically. They generally affect the front of the chest, face, and neck. 

The lesions are benign and are only treated for cosmetic reasons. Diathermy and carbon dioxide laser may be performed. However, diathermy has better cosmetic results while those treated with carbon dioxide laser recur. 

Syringoma is also known as

  • Hidradenomes eruptifs
  • Syringocystadenoma
  • Syringocystoma

Option A - Sebaceous adenomas are benign tumors of the sebaceous glands. They appear as yellow, smooth, circumscribed papules or nodules. They may be present on the face, scalp, and neck. 

Option C - Melanocytic nevi are benign tumors of melanocytes. They can be congenital or acquired. They have a varied presentation from even pigmentation to an array of colors. They should be differentiated from melanomas. 

Option D - Lipomas are benign tumors of adipocytes. They are slow-growing, rubbery nodules with a firm consistency. They usually occur on the trunk, shoulders, neck, and axillae.

questions.text: The histopathological slide given below is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The given slide shows a row of tombstones appearance, which is classically seen in pemphigus vulgaris. 

In this condition, there is a suprabasal splitting of the epidermis leading to blister formation. The basal layer remains adherent to the basement membrane and gives the resemblance to a row of tombstones as shown in the histology image below.

Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic immunobullous disorder characterized by the presence of antibodies against desmosomal proteins, desmogleins 1 and 3 expressed in the skin and mucosa.

Clinically, the patients present with ill-defined, irregular, slow-to-heal oral lesions and erosions. Flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid may arise on normal skin or an erythematous base. The rupture of such blisters produces painful erosions and heals without scarring.

Nikolsky's sign is positive which is elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger on lesional or perilesional skin. This leads to the separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis, producing erosion.

Direct immunofluorescence is considered the most accurate confirmatory test of this condition. It shows intercellular IgG and C3 deposition on the surface of keratinocytes throughout the epidermis in normal, perilesional skin, in a characteristic fishnet/chickenwire appearance as seen below.

questions.text: A medical student is visiting her grandmother, who is recovering from heart surgery. She decides to cheer her up by painting her nails. She notices that her nails look odd as seen below. What is this finding called?
questions.solution:
This image shows Beau’s lines which are generalized transverse grooves on the nail which may be full or partial thickness. They usually occur a few weeks after a precipitating systemic event like MI, measles, mumps, or pneumonia. 

Isolated transverse grooves in individual nails may occur due to trauma, inflammation, or neurological events.

Option B: Mees or Aldrich–Mees lines or Leukonychia striata are white lines that occur as a 1–2 mm wide transverse band is in the arcuate form of the lunula. They are associated with arsenic and lithium poisoning as well as renal failure.

Option C: Lindsay nails or half-and-half nails are a rare finding where the proximal portion of the nail is white and the distal half is pink, with a sharp line of demarcation between the two halves. They are specific for renal failure.

Option D: Trachyonychia is roughening of nails observed in alopecia areata.

questions.text: While examining a patient in the dermatology OPD, the senior resident elicits the following finding. What condition does this patient likely have?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of dermographism, which is commonly elicited in chronic urticaria patients.

It is an urticarial reaction in response to pressure or trauma to the skin. It is the most common type of inducible urticaria.

Simple dermographism or factitious urticaria refers to the triple response of local erythema due to: 

  1. Capillary vasodilatation
  2. Edema
  3. Surrounding flare 

The eliciting stimulus determines the shape of the wheals, but they are often linear from scratching or stroking.

In <5% of cases, symptomatic dermographism can occur. It is characterized by severe, disproportionate itching that is worse at night. 

Other rare forms of dermographism associated with urticaria are cholinergic dermographism, red dermographism, and delayed dermographism.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions would you expect to see Darier's sign?
questions.solution:
Darier's sign is seen in urticaria pigmentosa. It refers to the development of urticaria and erythema around the lesions after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of the lesion.

Urticaria pigmentosa is the most common pattern of cutaneous mastocytosis, which occurs due to an increased number of mast cells in the skin. It presents with reddish-brown or pale maculopapules, plaques, nodules in symmetric distribution, sparing the palms and soles.

Darier's sign is not specific for mastocytosis as it is also rarely seen in juvenile xanthogranuloma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

Note: Pseudo-Darier sign is seen in soft tissue hamartoma, with piloerection and transient induration after stroking the lesions. Darier's disease is an autosomal dominant disorder, characterized by hyperkeratotic papules and plaques along with nail changes.

questions.text: A 67-year-old diabetic comes to you with a rash over the intertriginous areas, which is more pronounced over his groin.  Wood's lamp examination shows coral pink fluorescence. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Coral pink fluorescence on Wood's lamp examination is characteristic of erythrasma.

Erythrasma is a skin infection caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum. It is common in diabetics and immunodeficient patients and is associated with obesity, sweating and poor hygiene.

Coral pink fluorescence is due to the production of coproporphyrin III by the bacterium.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement regarding the condition shown in the image below.

choices.text: Serine proteases degrade keratin in the horny layer
Often associated with malodour and maceration

questions.solution:
The above image shows numerous small, shallow, circular erosions with punched-out appearance over pressure bearing area of soles, characteristic of pitted keratolysis.

It is usually associated with hyperhidrosis (not anhidrosis). Pitted keratolysis is caused most commonly due to infection by Corynebacterium and also by Kytococcus sedentarius. The pits are produced by serine proteases that can degrade keratin in the horny layer.

Most patients are unaware of the condition due to minimal irritation. This condition is diagnosed by its clinical appearance. Cultures are not useful due to mixed infections.

Treatment of hyperhidrosis slowly brings the condition under control including potassium permanganate soaks, aluminum chloride, and iontophoresis. Topical fucidin ointment may be used.

questions.text: A patient presented with the following cutaneous finding to the dermatology OPD. Which of the following organisms is least likely to cause this?
questions.solution:
The serpiginous/serpent-like skin lesions seen are cutaneous larva migrans or larva currens. Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus are hookworms that cause human infection and are least likely to cause cutaneous larva migrans.

Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by non-human hookworms like Ancylostoma braziliense, Ancylostoma caninum acquired from direct skin contact with soil contaminated by dog or cat feces. 

Serpentine or linear single-track lines later mark the course of the larvae as they migrate through the epidermis of the trunk and lower extremities. Symptoms begin to appear within the first two weeks of the patient’s return from a tropical or endemic country. The larval track progresses at approximately 1 cm/h with cutaneous lesions only progressing a few millimeters to a few centimeters daily.

Larva currens aka 'running larva’ of Strongyloidiasis stercoralis. It is known for its distinct rapidity, with the larval track progressing at approximately 0.2 cm/min, with cutaneous lesions progressing up to 10 cm/hour. 

Ivermectin is the preferred treatment and is given at 0.15–0.2 mg/kg every day per oral for 1 or 2 days.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the condition shown below?

choices.text: Loss of sweat glands in distal extremities

questions.solution:
The image shows a young woman with mask-like facies with stretched, shiny skin, and loss of normal facial lines, microstomia, and pitted scarring on the right index finger which is suggestive of scleroderma or systemic sclerosis, an autoimmune rheumatic disease in which there is a 4: 1 female predominance.

Cutaneous features:

  • Hands and feet - Raynaud's phenomenon, non-pitting edema, painful ulcerations which heal with pitted scars, sclerodactyly, contractures, loss of sweat glands, bone resorption.
  • Face - periorbital edema, mask-like facies, telangiectasia, and diffuse hyperpigmentation
  • Trunk - firm, shiny, and thickened skin

The extent of skin sclerosis in systemic sclerosis can be measured, most commonly employing a modified Rodnan skin score (MRSS).

Systemic features:

  • GIT- dysphagia, GERD, diminished peristalsis, malabsorption
  • Lungs- pulmonary fibrosis and alveolitis
  • Heart- cardiac conduction defects, heart failure
  • Kidney- uremia, malignant hypertension
  • Musculoskeletal- weakness, carpal tunnel syndrome

The image below shows typical facial features: note the expressionless facies, mat‐like telangiectases, microstomia, perioral furrowing, and beak‐like nose.

The image below shows digital ulceration

The image below shows advanced‐stage sclerodactyly with contractures and vasculopathic ulcers over the bony prominences

In systemic sclerosis, progressive loss of fingerprints is seen in patients. These altered fingerprint ridges are seen due to changes in skin elasticity,  hardness, and thickness and eventually make a patient with scleroderma a “fingerprintless person”.

Autoantibody patterns seen in systemic sclerosis:

  • Reactivity to autoantibodies such as anticentromere (ACA) is commonly seen in limited skin sclerosis.
  • Reactivity to autoantibodies such as antitopoisomerase 1 antibody (anti‐Scl‐70 or ATA), and anti‐RNA polymerase III antibody (ARA or RNAP) is commonly seen in SSc.

questions.text: An elderly Australian man presented with a slowly progressing lesion on his scalp for 3 years. Which of the following is considered as a high-risk susceptibility gene for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a flat, brownish, irregularly shaped lesion suggestive of melanoma. The cyclin‐dependent kinase (CDK) inhibitor 2A gene (CDKN2A), located on chromosome 9p21, is the best established high‐risk locus for melanoma susceptibility.

CDKN2A mutations are found in approximately 40% of individuals with familial melanoma.

In melanoma, tumor suppressors that play a protective role against melanoma are mutated. CDKN2A encodes via alternative splicing for two proteins involved in cell cycle regulation: p16/Ink4a and p14/Arf, both act as tumor suppressors through the Rb and p53 cancer pathways, respectively.

questions.text: Histopathological examination would not reveal acantholysis in patients with:
questions.solution:
Acantholysis is not seen in bullous pemphigoid. It is seen in diseases like pemphigus, Darier's disease, and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome.

Acantholysis is the loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, leading to the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes. This results in the formation of intraepidermal clefts, vesicles, and bullae.

Acantholysis in pemphigus vulgaris affects the lower part of the epidermis while that in pemphigus foliaceus affects the upper part. In Hailey-Hailey disease, acantholysis affects the entire thickness of the epidermis.

Acantholysis may be classified as:

  • Primary acantholysis: Due to direct injury to or defects seen in desmosomes, separation of keratinocytes occurs, resulting in circular acantholytic cells. Acantholuysis is the primary event causing intraepidermal cavities. It is seen in conditions such as:
    • Pemphigus and its variants
    • Acantholytic dermatosis
    • Darier's disease
    • Hailey Hailey disease
    • Warty dyskeratoma
  • Secondary acantholysis: Due to the damage or alteration to the keratinocytes, leading to the dissolution of desmosomes. This results in acantholysis that is seen in:
    • Viral disorders like herpes simplex infections (HSV 1 and 2), varicella-zoster infections (chickenpox and shingles)
    • Bullous impetigo
    • Solar keratoses
    • Squamous cell carcinoma - some forms

The image below shows acantholysis and dyskeratosis as seen in Darier's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following types is the most common presentation of psoriatic arthritis?
questions.solution:
Asymmetric oligoarthritis is the most common type of Psoriatic arthritis.

Asymmetric oligoarthritis commonly involves a knee or another large joint with a few small joints in the fingers or toes, often with dactylitis.

Psoriatic arthritis is a seronegative inflammatory arthritis that is destructive to the joints, associated with moderate to severe psoriasis. It usually develops before 40 years of age.

A diagnosis of psoriatic arthritis can be made from the Classification Criteria for Psoriatic Arthritis (CASPAR) criteria, if there is an inflammatory articular disease of a joint, enthesis or spine, along with >=3 of the following criteria:

  1. Current or history of psoriasis/ family history of psoriasis
  2. Typical psoriatic nail involvement
  3. Rheumatoid factor negative
  4. Current or history of dactylitis
  5. Radiological evidence of juxta-articular new bone formation

Triggers include trauma to a joint or tendon (Koebner effect), smoking, alcohol excess and HIV infection. Streptococcal infection, medications like lithium or stress do not trigger the onset of psoriatic arthritis. There is an activation of both innate and acquired immunity with the overproduction of cytokines like TNF‐α, IL‐17 and IL‐23 via the JAK-STAT pathway. This results in joint fibrosis and erosion of bone with abnormal bone formation.

Wright & Moll Classification of Psoriatic Arthritis

  • Arthritis of the DIP joints
  • Asymmetric oligoarthritis
  • Symmetric polyarthritis
  • Axial involvement such as spine and sacroiliac joints
  • Arthritis mutilans, a destructive form of arthritis

Psoriatic arthritis involves proximal and distal interphalangeal joints (PIP, DIP) and metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP). Clinical features include:

  • Early morning stiffness
  • Swollen, tender, one or more joints
  • Enthesitis: Heel pain due to Achilles tendon inflammation
  • Plantar fasciitis
  • Dactylitis /sausage fingers with telescoping (shortening of toes due to osteolysis)
  • Nail changes: hyperkeratosis and onycholysis
  • Axial involvement may occur

The image below shows psoriatic arthritis of the hands:

 

Investigations include:

  • Inflammatory markers like CRP, ESR
  • Tests to rule out other arthritis: uric acid, rheumatoid factor, anti-CCP antibodies
  • Plain X‐rays of the hands and feet in erosive disease, which show:
    • Pencil-in-cup deformity of distal interphalangeal joint
    • Marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation 'whiskering'
  • MRI to assess axial disease and enthesitis

Given below is an X-ray showing the 'pencil-in-cup' appearance of the metacarpophalangeal joints

Psoriatic arthritis should be managed by a rheumatologist. Early treatment and interventions are necessary to prevent irreversible joint damage. The Group for Research and Assessment of Psoriasis and Psoriatic Arthritis (GRAPPA) management guidelines for psoriatic arthritis states the use of the following drugs in:

  • Peripheral arthritis: NSAIDs/ steroid injection/ Systemic treatments - methotrexate, cyclosporin/ biologicals
  • Dactylitis: NSAIDs/ Steroid injection
  • Axial disease / Enthesitis: NSAIDs / Physiotherapy / Biologicals

Tofacitinib is a novel, oral JAK 1/3 - Inhibitor which will inhibit the JAK-STAT pathway responsible for the production of cytokines and chemokines. It has been approved for the treatment of psoriatic arthritis, and is also used in rheumatoid arthritis and ulcerative colitis.

Newer drugs approved for the treatment of Psoriatic arthritis include:

Class of drug Drugs
Anti-TNF α

- Infliximab (only iv drug, rest all are s/c)
- Etanercept 
- Adalimumab 
- Golimumab
- Certolizumab
Anti-IL-17 - Secukinumab 
Anti-IL-23 - Ustekinumab 

Psoriatic arthritis is found to be associated with ocular diseases like conjunctivitis, uveitis, iridocyclitis, keratoconjunctivitis sicca and cataracts, obesity/metabolic syndrome, alcohol misuse and premature cardiovascular disease.

Differential diagnoses include:

  • Early rheumatoid arthritis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Gout
  • Osteoarthritis
  • Fibromyalgia

Asymmetric oligoarthritis is the most common type of psoriatic arthritis. Previously, symmetric polyarthritis was marked as the correct answer (based on Harrison's Textbook of Internal Medicine 20th Edition). However, after thorough review of literature and consultation of expert faculty, the answer has been changed to asymetric oligoarthritis as per:

  • Rook′s Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition - (Page no 35.44) 
  • ABC of Rheumatology 2018, Wiley-Blackwell- British Medical Journal (Page No 85)
  • Kelley and Firestein's Textbook of Rheumatology, 10th Edition (Page No 1288)

questions.text: A 50-year old patient presented with scaly plaques, well-demarcated from unaffected skin, with sharply delineated edges as shown in the image given below. The lesions showed an isomorphic response and the Auspitz sign was positive. Which of the following types is the most common variant of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of psoriasis, with the image showing well-demarcated scaly plaques surrounded by Woronoff's rings. Plaque psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis.

Plaque/Discoid psoriasis, also known as psoriasis vulgaris accounts for almost 90% of all psoriasis cases. It presents as a papulosquamous rash, with reddish edematous plaques covered with silvery-white scales, which are well-demarcated from unaffected skin with sharply delineated edges. Plaques may be encircled by a clear peripheral zone called the halo or ring of Woronoff. The scalp is one of the most common and first affected areas in plaque psoriasis.

Psoriasis is a proliferative and inflammatory condition of the skin characterized by erythematous plaques covered with silver scales. It generally affects the extensor surfaces, scalp, and lumbosacral region. The peak on occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years. They usually present with itching and a papulosquamous rash

It is linked to infiltration of the skin by activated T cells which cause proliferation of keratinocytes. This leads to the formation of thick plaques, epidermal hyperplasia, and parakeratosis. 

It can occur in sites of cutaneous trauma and old scarring, termed as Koebner's phenomenon. It is suggested that trauma stimulates immune activation. Plaque psoriasis is the most common type of psoriasis and is seen in 80-90% of patients.

The image below shows Koebner's phenomenon seen in plaque psoriasis.

Various factors contribute to the exacerbation of psoriasis.

Drugs inducing/exacerbating psoriasis:

  1. Beta-blockers
  2. Synthetic antimalarials
  3. NSAIDS
  4. Lithium
  5. ACE inhibitors & angiotensin receptor blockers
  6. Interferon alpha
  7. Tetracycline
  8. Terbinafine
  9. Gemfibrozil

Other environmental and immunological factors that may trigger psoriasis are:

  • Infections- beta-hemolytic streptococci can trigger guttate psoriasis
  • Alcohol misuse and smoking
  • Emotional stress
  • Trauma - Koebner phenomenon
  • Winter 
  • Sunlight

Lesions can be described as:

  • Red, scaly, and have well demarcation from the normal skin.
  • Encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring.
  • Appear in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

It can also be classified based on the site involved:

  • Plaque psoriasis (most common): sharply demarcated erythematous plaques with silvery scales, commonly present on extensor surfaces (elbows, knees, etc.)
  • Guttate psoriasis: small scattered erythematous papules with silvery scales; often triggered by infections
  • Erythrodermic psoriasis: confluent plaques affecting nearly all of the skin but often sparing the central face, with electrolyte and thermoregulation abnormalities
  • Pustular psoriasis: presence of superficial pustules; generalized, annular, palmar-plantar, localized and exanthemic variants are described
  • Scalp psoriasis: well demarcated plaques on the retroauricular areas and posterior upper neck
  • Flexural/ inverse psoriasis: plaques affecting intertriginous folds, scaling may be less prominent
  • Napkin psoriasis: may be seen in napkin (diaper) area in newborns
  • Nail psoriasis: pits, splinter hemorrhages, oil drop sign (translucent yellow discoloration of the nail caused by parakeratosis of the nail bed), salmon patches and leukonychia are common on the nail plate

  • Signs:

    • Koebner phenomenon: new psoriatic papules at sites of skin trauma
    • Auspitz sign: pinpoint bleeding when scales are removed

Woronoff ring: an area of blanching surrounding resolving psoriatic plaques

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.

Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.

Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.

Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

  • P – Pitting
  • O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis
  • L – Leuconychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Hemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

Vitiligo

Lichen planus

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

questions.text: Under normal circumstances, the percentage of hair follicles on the human scalp, present in anagen of the hair cycle are _______
questions.solution:
Hair Cycle is usually described under three phases: Anagen, Catagen and Telogen. At any given time, under normal circumstances, 80–90% of hair follicles on the human scalp are in anagen phase of growth.

Related Pearl: Hair Cycle

Hair follicles undergo a repetitive sequence of growth and the rest is known as the hair cycle. Hair Cycle is usually described under three phases: Anagen, Catagen, and Telogen.

1. Anagen

  • The period of active hair growth is known as anagen and the duration of this phase is responsible for determining the final length of the hair.
  • The entry of a resting hair follicle into anagen is heralded by the onset of mitotic activity in epithelial cells overlying the dermal papilla at the base of the follicle (the secondary epithelial germ).
  • Under normal circumstances, 80–90% of hair follicles on the human scalp are in anagen at any one time.
  • Anagen can continue for several years.

Fig 1. Scalp hair follicle in the anagen II stage of development

Fig 2.  Anagen hair bulb. Co, hair cortex; Cu, hair cuticle; DP, dermal papilla; DS, dermal sheath; He, Henle layer; HM, hair matrix; Hu, Huxley layer; IRSCu, inner root sheath cuticle; Me, melanocyte; ORS, outer root sheath

2. Catagen

  • At the end of anagen, epithelial cell division declines and ceases, and the follicle enters an involutionary phase known as catagen.
  • During catagen, the proximal end of the hair shaft keratinizes to form a club-shaped structure and the lower part of the follicle involutes by apoptosis.
  • The basement membrane surrounding the follicle becomes thickened and corrugated to form the ‘glassy membrane’.
  • It lasts for about 10 days.

Fig 3.  Human hair follicle in mid-catagen. There is a prominent glassy membrane surrounding the regressing epithelial column. The dermal papilla is rounded and condensed. 

3. Telogen

  • It is the time period between catagen and the next anagen.
  • It lasts for about 3 months.
  • Club hair is eventually shed through an active process called exogen.
  • In the human scalp, hair follicles may remain in a state of latency, also known as kenogen, for a pro­longed period after the club hair is shed.

questions.text: Triad of tenosynovitis, dermatitis and migratory asymmetric polyarthralgia is _________

questions.text: Which of the following statements are false about lepromatous leprosy?

choices.text: The longest peripheral sensory nerves are affected first
Radiographic changes show cysts and osteoporosis
Sensation of palms and soles is lost early in the disease
bilaterally symmetrical distribution of skin lesions can occur anywhere apart from hairy scalp, axillae, groins and perineum

questions.solution:
In lepromatous leprosy sensation of palms and soles is retained until late in the disease. The longest peripheral sensory nerves are affected first, causing numbness and anesthesia on the dorsal surfaces of hands and feet, and later on extensor surfaces of arms and legs, and finally over the trunk.

Radiographs may show osteoporosis in the phalanges, small osteolytic cysts and often hairline or compression fractures.
Regions of skin with a higher temperature like hairy scalp, axillae, groins, and perineum do not typically show lesions of Lepromatous leprosy.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions do not show pseudo-Pautrier's microabscesses on histopathology?
questions.solution:

Pseudo Pautrier’s microabscesses are described as spongiotic stimulants of Pautrier's microabscesses and consist of Langerhans cells, histiocytes, stellate keratinocytes, and rare lymphocytes. They are also seen in mycosis fungoides. 

Carbamazepine induced skin lesions resemble and show skin biopsy features of MF. Condition undergoes remission after drug discontinuation. Spongiotic and lichenoid dermatitis also show pseudo Pautrier's microabscesses.

questions.text: A factory worker comes to you with itchy, annular scaly plaques in the groin. On prescribing corticosteroids ointment, there is significant relief in pruritus but the lesion continues to extend peripherally. What is the likely diagnosis?

Steroids cause relief from itching but do not cause cure of the infection.

Treatment:- Terbinafine or Itraconazole or Fluconazole or Griseofulvin for 2-4 weeks.

Culture is done on Feinberg-Whittington media.

questions.text: A patient with a known case of dermatosis developed new skin lesions at the site of injury on previously healthy skin. Which of the following conditions shows a similar response?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Koebner phenomenon. Psoriasis shows Koebner phenomenon.

Koebner/isomorphic phenomenon refers to the appearance of new skin lesions on healthy skin at the site of cutaneous injury, in the presence of a pre-existing dermatosis. They are typically linear, as they follow the route of the injury.

Koebner phenomenon is diagnosed clinically using the following characteristics:

  • Linear lesions developing at the site of cutaneous injury on a previously healthy skin
  • Lesions have the same clinical and histological features as the underlying dermatosis
  • Lesions are not due to seeding of an infectious agent, allergic reaction or skin breakdown

The exact cause of such a response is unclear. Theories involving T-cell mediated response, involvement of dermis, and microvasculature are considered. Various triggers for Koebner phenomenon have been identified:

  • Trauma: Insect and animal bites, burns including thermal and electric, excoriation, friction, shaving, lacerations, cryotherapy, pressure sores, and orthotics
  • Chemical irritation: Tattoo associated skin reaction, BCG vaccination, tuberculin skin test, hair dye allergy
  • Diseases: Urticaria, inflammatory dermatoses
  • Others: Phototherapy, sunburn, withdrawal of methotrexate therapy

Other features of Koebner phenomenon include:

  • Graded response to trauma: Intensity of response to trauma is unique to each patient and the underlying disease.
    • No Koebner response to injury
    • Abortive Koebner response: Lesions appear, but spontaneously vanish after a few weeks
    • Minimal Koebner response: Lesions develop at the site of trauma
    • Maximal Koebner response: Widespread lesions develop across the entire site of trauma
  • All or nothing response: Patients who develop Koebner phenomenon in response to one type of injury, may develop a similar response due to other types of injuries as well. In case, a patient does not exhibit Koebner phenomenon to one type of injury, it is unlikely that it is exhibited after any other type of injury.
  • Time taken to develop the skin lesions is unique to the patient and the specific dermatosis. It may vary from 3 days to 2 years, normally taking around 10-20 days.

Koebner phenomenon can be classified into:

  • True Koebnerisation: New skin lesions seen with the clinical features mentioned above, as seen in vitiligo, psoriasis and lichen planus.  
  • Pseudo-Koebnerisation: Appearance of similar skin lesions at the site of injury in infective lesions like plane warts and molluscum contagiosum, due to the spread of the infective agent (virus) to the new site by seeding, especially due to scratching.

The image below shows Koebner phenomenon seen in a psoriatic patient at the site of trauma.

Koebner phenomenon is also seen in other diseases like:

  • Erythema multiforme
  • Lichen nidatus
  • Necrobiosis lipodica
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Hailey-Hailey disease
  • Darier disease
  • Vasculitis
  • Pityriasis rubra pilaris

Other phenomena associated with cutaneous trauma are:

  • Reverse Koebner phenomenon: Disappearance of skin lesions after trauma to the area, which is seen in psoriasis after dermabrasion or surgery.
  • Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon: Spontaneous repigmentation is seen in distant patches after autologous skin graft surgery in vitiligo.
  • Wolf's isotopic response/isotopic phenomenon: Emergence of new dermatosis at the site of a previous unrelated dermatosis as seen in granuloma annulare developing at the site of herpes zoster and psoriasis developing at the site of contact dermatitis.
  • Pathergy: Occurance of non-specific papules and pustules secondary to heavy neutrophilic infiltrates after an injection or venipuncture, as seen in pyoderma gangrenosum and Behçet disease.
  • Renbök/inverse Koebner phenomenon: Disappearance of an existing skin condition after the onset of a new dermatosis at the same site, as seen in retention of hair follicles on the psoriatic plaques on the scalp while hair loss was present in unaffected areas of alopecia areata. 

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

Oral lichen planus is associated with Wickham striae in the oral cavity. They are fine white lines in a lacy or fern-like pattern that cross the plaques in lichen planus.

questions.text: Wrinkles on the forehead of an old lady are due to decrease in ______
questions.solution:
Wrinkling is due to elastotic degeneration.

Wrinkles are a characteristic of ageing skin. They may be defined as creases or furrows in the skin surface.

There are three morphological types of wrinkles:

  • Crinkles
  • Glyphic wrinkles
  • Linear furrows

questions.text: Which component of cement causes allergic dermatitis among construction workers in India?
questions.solution:
Chromate is the most frequent allergen in cement causing occupational contact dermatitis. The most common allergen causing allergic contact dermatitis in India is nickel. It is commonly found in artificial jewelry. However, among construction workers, chromate is more common than nickel. The reported prevalence of allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) to chromate among construction workers is usually more than 10%. 

Allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) is an inflammatory condition caused due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction (Type 4 hypersensitivity) to a specific allergen that comes into direct contact with the skin. Some common allergens include nickel (found in artificial jewelry), PPD/Para phenylene diamine (in hair dye), chromate (in cement), rubber or latex, cosmetics, etc. Patch test is used for the diagnosis of ACD.

Patients usually present with pruritus, erythema, swelling, papules, and papulovesicles. In severe cases, large vesicles or blisters may form due to the disruption of the intercellular bridges. If exposure persists the affected area becomes dry, scaly, and thicker with lichenification and fissuring develops later. There is involvement of the covered areas as well as the exposed areas.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is biopsied for the diagnosis of pure neuritic leprosy?
questions.solution:
Superficial sensory branch of the radial nerve is most commonly used for nerve biopsy in neuritic leprosy.

Although any nerve involved would show the pathology, it is prudent to biopsy a branch of a sensory nerve, rather than a mixed nerve or major nerve trunk. So, the ulnar nerve will not be the best answer despite it being the most common peripheral nerve involved in neuritic leprosy.

The common nerves and sites where nerve biopsy is performed in leprosy are as follows:

  • Superficial sensory radial nerve branch at the wrist
  • Ulnar cutaneous nerve near the ulnar border of the base of the hand
  • Sural nerve near the ankle

Note: Nerve biopsy is the gold standard for confirmation of pure neuritic leprosy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the condition given below?

choices.text: Two forms of the disease are recognized: bullous and non-bullous
This can occur from either streptococcal or staphylococcal infection
Oral antibiotics are more effective than topical antibiotics
Disease is self-limiting and resolves with antibiotics and skin cleansers

questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of Impetigo.

Oral antibiotics and topical antibiotics are equally effective in mild-moderate disease.

If the infection is widespread or severe, or is accompanied by lymphadenopathy, then an oral antibiotic such as flucloxacillin or erythromycin is indicated. Topical retapamulin, a relatively new topical antibiotic is also effective in treating impetigo.

questions.text: The following is a pre-malignant condition?
questions.solution:
Actinic cheilitis is a premalignant condition.

It is a premalignant keratosis of the lip caused by prolonged exposure to the sun. It is also called sailor’s lip or solar cheilosis.

Actinic cheilitis tends to affect the lower lip of adults. Initially there is redness and edema. Then, the epithelium becomes palpably thickened with small greyish‐white plaques and, eventually, warty nodules may form.

Biopsy may be required to diagnose it.

Treatment:

  • Topical agents: 5% fluorouracil three times daily for 10 days is suitable. Topical tretinoin, trichloracetic acid or diclofenac gel may also be effective.
  • Vermilionectomy (lip shave)
  • Laser ablation
  • Photodynamic therapy sometimes also with imiquimod.

Following treatment, the regular use of a sunscreen lip salve containing p ‐aminobenzoic acid probably gives the best protection.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about scleredema is false?

choices.text: Mucin accumulation in skeletal muscle and heart
Erythema and peau d’orange appearance of skin

questions.solution:
The epidermis is not involved in scleredema. However, the dermis is involved and is 3-4 times thicker than normal.

Scleredema is symmetrical diffuse progressive non‐pitting swelling and induration of the upper part of the body caused by a thickened dermis and deposition of mucin (skeletal muscle and heart).

Scleredema can be divided into a diabetic and non‐diabetic type. The former is considered the most common type accounting for 25–50% of cases.

The non‐diabetic type is caused by:

  • Post-infective (streptococcal upper respiratory infection, influenza, measles, mumps, dental abscesses)
  • Autoimmune disorders (rheumatoid arthritis, primary biliary cirrhosis, Sjogren syndrome, dermatomyositis, anaphylactoid purpura)
  • Internal malignancies (malignant insulinoma, gallbladder carcinoma, carcinoid tumour, pituitary–adrenocortical neoplasms)

It typically begin on the posterior neck and spread to the upper back, shoulders and scalp.

Erythema and peau d’orange appearance of the skin are observed. The hands and feet are characteristically spared.

Treatment:

First-line

  • Treatment of primary disease
  • Phototherapy with UVA1, PUVA or narrow‐band UVB
  • Physical therapy

Second line

  • Electron‐beam radiotherapy
  • Photopheresis
  • Intravenous immunoglobulin

Third line

  • Immunosuppressive agents

 

Note: Scleredema is not to be confused with scleroderma.

 

Scleredema includes:

• Buschke disease

• Scleredema adultorum of Buschke

• Scleredema adultorum

• Scleredema diabeticorum

questions.text: A 50-year-old post-renal transplant patient on cyclosporine presented with the following lesion. You suspect it to be a cancerous growth. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is false?

choices.text: It has a high grade malignant potential
The most common site is extremities

questions.solution:
The above image showing purple-colored plaques on the ala and tip of the nose in an immunocompromised patient is suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma. It is mostly seen in extremities, commonly on feet and occasionally on hands, ears, and nose, and has a low-grade malignant potential.

Skin lesions are usually purple and multifocal which eventually evolve into plaques and tumors. Lymph nodes, mucosae, and viscera may be involved as the disease progresses, although this can occur without skin involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the clinical triad of Sézary syndrome?

choices.text: Atypical mononuclear cells > 20% of total lymphocytes

questions.solution:
Seborrhoeic keratosis is not a part of the clinical triad of Sézary syndrome 

The clinical triad of Sézary syndrome consists of the following:

  1. Erythroderma - As a result of diffuse infiltration of the skin by neoplastic cells 
  2. Peripheral lymphadenopathy
  3. Atypical mononuclear cells (Sézary cells) comprising more than 20% of total lymphocyte count or total Sézary count of more than 1000 × 109/L

questions.text: Which of the following features is incorrect regarding basal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Basal cell carcinoma typically has no premalignant stage.

The typical basal cell carcinoma runs a slowly progressive course of peripheral extension. The pearly translucent nodule with surface telangiectasia undergoes central necrosis resulting in rodent ulcer with a rolled-out margin.

Metastasis is extremely rare in basal cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A 58-year-old lady presents with pain, swelling, and discoloration in her left thumb for 4 months. On examination, the following clinical sign is noted. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
The above image shows melanonychia with the pigmentation of proximal nail fold which is called the Hutchinson's sign. It is seen in subungual melanoma.

In benign nail pigmentation due to drugs (eg. minocycline) or injury (hematoma), the colour stays within the margins of the nail plate and doesn't extend to nail folds.

Option A: Frank's sign - diagonal crease in the earlobes of adults has been associated with an increased risk for atherosclerotic heart disease.

Option B: Fitzpatrick sign (Dimple sign) - squeezing the skin adjacent to a dermatofibroma causes a dimpled appearance on its surface. It is also termed a positive pinch sign or dimple sign.

Option D: Pastia's sign - linear petechial eruption in the skin folds especially on the ante-cubital fossa and axillary fold seen in streptococcal scarlet fever.

questions.text: A young woman presented to the OPD with the following rash. She also complained of myalgia, arthralgia, and hair loss. Her history was significant for sun-induced skin problems. Lupus band test was found to be positive only in the involved skin. Which of the following antibodies is closely associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a psoriasiform papulosquamous lesion on the sun-exposed area(back). Along with the history and the positive lupus band test only in the involved skin, a diagnosis of subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus can be made. Antibodies to the Ro/SS‐A antigen are almost universally present in this subgroup. 

Subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus is a specific ‘subset’ of lupus in which patients exhibit mainly cutaneous disease and usually have a good prognosis.

The lupus band test (LBT) is a direct immunofluorescence technique for demonstrating a band of localized immunoglobulins at the dermal-epidermal junction in the skin of patients with lupus erythematosus (LE).

questions.text: A model presents to the OPD with the following cutaneous lesions. She informs the dermatologist that these lesions increase in size whenever she consumes alcohol and that they bleed whenever she scratches them. Which of the following is false regarding the pathogenesis of her condition?

choices.text: Deficient Th1 and Th17 helper cells
IFN-γ, TNF-α, IL-17 levels are raised

questions.solution:
The image shows sharply marginated, dull-red plaques with silvery-white scales which have coalesced to form geographical lesions. The history and image point towards a diagnosis of psoriasis. Here, there is an increased number of activated Th1, Th17, and Th22 cells, with a deficiency of Th2 cells.

It is a common, chronic, immune-mediated inflammatory condition in which multiple genetic and environmental factors may lead to the formation of erythematous plaques with silvery-white scales. Genetic predisposition is present in type 1 plaque psoriasis and guttate psoriasis with HLA‐C:06:02.

There is increased keratinocyte turnover. It normally takes 30 days for basal keratinocytes to reach the surface but in patients with psoriasis, this is reduced to 4-5 days.

The activation of T cells of the adaptive immune system, specifically Th17 cells, in turn, activates keratinocytes to proliferate and produce multiple chemokines and antimicrobial peptides. 

Cytokines in psoriasis:

Increased Decreased

Inflammatory cells and cytokines

 Anti-inflammatory cells and cytokines
Th1 and Th17 cells   Th2 cells

IL‐2, IL‐8, IFN‐γ, TNF‐α, IL‐15, IL-17, IL‐22, and IL‐23

IL-4 and IL-10 absent

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about dermatomyositis?

choices.text: Dysphagia points to a worse prognosis

questions.solution:
Muscle tenderness is uncommon in dermatomyositis.

Dermatomyositis is an autoimmune disorder affecting, predominantly, the skin and skeletal muscle.

It usually presents initially with a facial rash especially around eyelids which can be pruritic and sore. Myositis symptoms are usually weakness and fatigue especially while climbing stairs, raising arms and standing from sitting due to proximal muscle weakness.

The presence of dysphagia points to a poorer prognosis.

questions.text: The modified Rodnan skin score is used to assess the severity of skin involvement in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The extent of skin sclerosis in systemic sclerosis can be measured, most commonly employing a modified Rodnan skin score (MRSS).

By this method, the degree of skin sclerosis is scored from 0 to 3 by manual palpation at 17 different body sites giving a maximum score of 51.

The scoring of each skin region is determined by skin thickness and tethering:

  • 0 = Normal
  • 1 = Possible thickening
  • 2 = Unable to pinch the skin
  • 3 = Unable to move the skin (fixed to deeper tissues)

Other methods to monitor skin thickness are:

  • Durometry
  • 20 MHz ultrasonography
  • Optical coherence tomography (OCT)

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a chronic skin condition is noted to have areas of linear discontinuation over his skin. What is this finding called?
questions.solution:
A linear crack or discontinuation of the skin surface is called a fissure.

Option A: Ulcer refers to a loss of dermis and epidermis, often involving underlying tissue as well.

Option B: Excoriation refers to loss of skin substance, specifically produced by scratching.

Option C: Erosion refers to a loss of the epidermis, which heals without scarring. It commonly follows a blister.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases cannot be diagnosed by Tzanck smear?
questions.solution:
Hansen's disease is diagnosed by slit skin smear for acid-fast bacilli using the modified Ziehl-Neelsen technique.

Related Pearl: Tzanck Smear in Dermatology

The Tzanck smear, introduced by the Frenchman Tzanck, is a simple to perform, inexpensive bed side cytological test that aids in the diagnosis of vesicular, pustular and bullous diseases, in particular herpes.

The sensitivity of the Tzanck smear exceeds 80%, and the specificity 90% when the investigators are experienced.

Preparation of Tzanck smear:

  • Viral infections and Blistering disorders - fresh vesicle or intact blister is de-roofed and base is scraped 
  • Suspected tumors - any crust should be removed from ulcerated tumors, and non-ulcerated tumors should be incised with a sharp, pointed scalpel and sample is then obtained with either a blunt scalpel or a small curette
  • The smear should preferably be fixed immediately using Formol-Zenker solution since significant artifacts can result from drying.
  • Tzanck smear can be stained by a variety of methods, most commonly by Giemsa stain. Other stains used are hematoxylin and eosin, Wright, methylene blue, Papanicolaou and toluidine blue. 

Results in Tzanck Smear:

A typical Tzanck cell is a large round keratinocyte with a hypertrophic nucleus, hazy or absent nucleoli, and abundant basophilic cytoplasm. The basophilic staining is deeper peripherally on the cell membrane ("mourning edged" cells) due to the cytoplasm's tendency to get condensed at the periphery, leading to a perinuclear halo.

questions.text: What test is being performed in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The test depicted in the given image is diascopy.

It involves pressing a glass slide or a stiff, clear, colorless piece of plastic onto the skin to cause blanching by compressing blood out of small vessels. This allows other colors to be evaluated.

Some uses of diascopy are as follows: 

  • Apple jelly nodules -  Yellow-brown lesions seen in lupus vulgaris and sarcoidosis.
  • Spider naevi - Compression of radiating arterioles is noted. 
  • Differentiation of erythema (disappears) and purpura (remains unaltered).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the test shown below?

choices.text: Patients back is positioned 15 cm from the front panel of lamps

questions.solution:
The given image shows a photo-patch test. Skin reaction is seen on the uncovered side that is exposed to UV rays.

Photo-patch test is useful in the diagnosis of photosensitive rashes and photoallergic contact dermatitis that are typically localized to the sun-exposed areas of the skin.

UV light is used at a dose sufficient to trigger the photoallergic response, without causing a false positive phototoxic reaction. It is performed like a conventional patch test, except two sets of allergens are applied over the back. The control set of allergens and the rest of the skin are covered with an opaque material. The patient is positioned 15 cm from a UV lamp and the test site is irradiated with UV light.

This test is best read after 48 hours. In the case of a positive test indicating photoallergy, the exposed side shows a reaction.

questions.text: Choose the correct option with respect to the histopathological finding shown below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows intercellular edema involving the stratum spinosum which is suggestive of spongiosis. Spongiosis is the characteristic histopathological feature of acute eczema. 

In contrast, ballooning degeneration is a term that refers to the intracellular edema occurring in the stratum spinosum. This results in acantholysis. Ballooning degeneration is often seen secondary to viral infections like herpes. 

The image below shows ballooning degeneration (intracellular edema is seen).

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presented with purple, pruritic plaques on the flexor aspect of the left forearm for 7 months. A history suggestive of Koebner's phenomenon was elicited. A skin biopsy done is shown below. Identify the structure marked.
questions.solution:
The given scenario with symptoms of purple, itchy, plaque exhibiting Koebner's phenomenon is suggestive of lichen planus. It is characterized by the presence of Civatte bodies or colloid bodies as seen in the image above. 

The colloid body is a homogeneous, eosinophilic, rounded body resulting from the degeneration and death of keratinocytes, particularly in the lower layers of the epidermis. This structure is found in various lichenoid tissue reactions.

Option A: Copper penny bodies are seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Option C: Donovan bodies are seen in granuloma inguinale.
